name: Þjórsárdalur
description: Þjórsárdalur is a remote and historically significant valley in South Iceland carved by the Þjórsá river, Iceland's longest river at 230 kilometers, located approximately 100 kilometers northeast of Reykjavík in the highlands north of Mount Hekla. This verdant valley surrounded by barren volcanic highlands offers a remarkable concentration of natural wonders and archaeological treasures, making it one of Iceland's most rewarding off-the-beaten-path destinations for visitors willing to navigate challenging gravel roads. The valley's most famous resident was Stöng, a prosperous Viking Age farmstead that was catastrophically buried under thick layers of volcanic ash when Mount Hekla erupted violently in 1104 AD. This apocalyptic eruption, one of Hekla's most devastating in recorded history, forced the abandonment of the entire valley and preserved the farm structures beneath ash in a manner similar to Pompeii's preservation by Mount Vesuvius. Archaeological excavations beginning in 1939 uncovered the remarkably well-preserved stone and turf foundations of the longhouse, revealing details of 12th-century Icelandic life. A full-scale reconstruction called Þjóðveldisbærinn (Commonwealth Farm) was built nearby in 1974 using authentic medieval building techniques, allowing visitors to experience how Viking Age Icelanders lived in the centuries following settlement. The reconstruction features a turf-roofed longhouse with central hearth, sleeping benches along walls, a separate smithy, and a church, all built using traditional materials and methods.

opening_hours.valley_access: Summer only (late May to early October), best June-September
opening_hours.road_status: Highland roads close in winter, check www.road.is before visiting
opening_hours.vehicle_requirements: 4x4 REQUIRED for Háifoss and some attractions due to rough gravel roads
opening_hours.access_route: Route 32 from Route 30 near Flúðir, 1 hour 45 minutes from Reykjavík
opening_hours.stong_viking_farm: Reconstructed 1974 using authentic medieval techniques, original buried 1104 AD
opening_hours.thjodveldisbaerinn: Commonwealth Farm reconstruction - turf longhouse, smithy, church
opening_hours.gjain_gorge: 2.1 km round-trip from Stöng (15 min each way), moss-covered canyon with waterfalls
opening_hours.gjafoss_waterfall: Small picturesque waterfall in Gjáin gorge, lush vegetation
opening_hours.haifoss: 122m tall (Iceland's 4th tallest), viewpoint accessible via rough 4x4 road
opening_hours.granni_waterfall: Neighboring waterfall to Háifoss, creates double waterfall vista
opening_hours.protected_status: Gjáin, Háifoss, Granni, and Hjálparfoss preserved since 2020
opening_hours.hekla_eruption: 1104 AD eruption buried valley under ash, preserved Viking farm like Pompeii
opening_hours.archaeological_site: 1939 excavations revealed well-preserved Viking Age structures
opening_hours.recommended_time: Full day to explore all major sites within valley
opening_hours.safety_notes: Check road conditions, 4x4 essential, summer only access, highland driving experience recommended
